subject: Re: [junit] Re: Categories in 4.8, how can I avoid specifying classes 	in @Suite.SuiteClasses
msgSnippet: Hi. Georg and David. Thanks for your replies. The classpath-suite might be a good solution. Unfortunately it does not seem to support Categories, thoug. I
messageBody:
Hi. Georg and David.

Thanks for your replies.
The classpath-suite might be a good solution. Unfortunately it does not seem
to support Categories, thoug.

I changed my Suite from

@RunWith(Categories.class)
@...(SlowTests.class)
@...({AppTest.class})
public class SlowTestSuite {
}

To:
@RunWith(ClasspathSuite.class)
@...(SlowTests.class)
public class SlowTestSuite {
}

Then my "FastTests" are also run, not only the SlowTests.

David, do you think you can implement Categories in your filtering aka
@ClassnameFilters?

Thanks
B�rd

On Sun, Dec 13, 2009 at 12:45 PM, Georg <le_garcon_enerve@...> wrote:

>
>
> Hi!
>
> I implemented something like this and posted it on github.
> Essentially, the modified Suite matches a regexp against all classes in the
> class path and executes those matching (this is there is one to exclude
> others, too). However, this only works for entire classes and not for
> individual tests.
>
> Cheers,
> Georg
>

> > One way to do this is to subclass the Suite runner and pass the array of
> classes to the Suite constructor. How you generate that array from the

> that:
> >
> > http://code.google.com/p/reflections/
